title: Syringomyelia
scope: ** Evaluation and management of syringomyelia (fluid-filled cavity within the spinal cord) including Chiari I malformation-associated syrinx, post-traumatic syringomyelia, tumor-associated syrinx, post-inflammatory/post-infectious syrinx, tethered cord-associated syrinx, and idiopathic syringomyelia. Covers diagnostic workup, identification of underlying etiology, surgical indications (posterior fossa decompression, shunt placement, tumor resection, untethering), conservative management, symptomatic treatment (neuropathic pain, spasticity, bladder dysfunction), and long-term monitoring protocols. Excludes isolated Chiari malformation without syrinx, acute traumatic spinal cord injury (initial management), and intramedullary spinal cord tumors as primary diagnosis (see separate templates).

Essential/First-line.item: MRI entire spine (cervical, thoracic, lumbar) without and with gadolinium contrast
Essential/First-line.timing: STAT if acute neurologic deterioration; URGENT for new/progressive symptoms; ROUTINE for outpatient evaluation
Essential/First-line.target: Syrinx cavity (T1 hypointense, T2 hyperintense intramedullary cavity); location, length, and diameter of syrinx; associated Chiari malformation (cerebellar tonsillar herniation >5 mm below foramen magnum); intramedullary or extramedullary tumor; cord tethering; arachnoid cysts; arachnoiditis; cord atrophy
Essential/First-line.contraindications: GFR <30 (relative — give contrast if needed); gadolinium allergy (premedicate); pacemaker/implant (MRI-conditional protocol)

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain without and with gadolinium contrast
Essential/First-line.timing: URGENT for Chiari-associated syrinx; to evaluate posterior fossa anatomy, hydrocephalus, and brain pathology
Essential/First-line.target: Chiari I malformation (tonsillar ectopia >5 mm); Chiari II malformation (myelomeningocele-associated); posterior fossa crowding; small posterior fossa volume; hydrocephalus; brain tumor causing tonsillar herniation
Essential/First-line.contraindications: GFR <30 (relative — give contrast if needed); gadolinium allergy (premedicate); pacemaker/implant (MRI-conditional protocol)

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consult for diagnosis confirmation, etiology workup, severity grading, and differentiation from other causes of myelopathy
Neurosurgery consult for surgical candidacy evaluation in symptomatic or progressive syringomyelia, Chiari decompression assessment, and shunt consideration
Physical therapy for gait training, balance assessment, fall prevention, strengthening of affected extremities, and sensory compensation strategies
Occupational therapy for fine motor assessment, hand dexterity rehabilitation, ADL adaptation, assistive device fitting, and home safety evaluation given upper extremity weakness and sensory loss

Pain management referral for refractory neuropathic pain not responding to first-line and second-line agents, or for consideration of interventional procedures (spinal cord stimulation, intrathecal drug delivery)
Urology for neurogenic bladder evaluation, urodynamic testing, and management of urinary retention or incontinence from autonomic tract involvement
Rehabilitation medicine (physiatry) for comprehensive functional assessment, rehabilitation program coordination, and long-term disability management
Genetics referral if familial Chiari malformation or connective tissue disorder (Ehlers-Danlos syndrome) suspected as contributing to craniocervical instability
Pulmonology for respiratory function assessment if high cervical syrinx (C3-C5) with diaphragmatic weakness or if Chiari-associated central sleep apnea suspected
Social work for discharge planning, durable medical equipment coordination, disability assessment, and caregiver support
Psychology or psychiatry for adjustment disorder, depression, and anxiety related to chronic progressive neurologic disability

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately if sudden worsening of weakness, new inability to walk, loss of bowel or bladder control, or difficulty breathing (may indicate acute syrinx expansion or cord compression requiring emergency intervention)
Return to ED immediately if severe sudden headache, neck stiffness, or vomiting develops (may indicate Chiari-related complications such as hydrocephalus or CSF obstruction)
Avoid high-risk activities including contact sports, heavy lifting, vigorous straining (Valsalva maneuvers), and activities with risk of spinal trauma (risk of syrinx expansion or cord injury)
Use caution with temperature extremes; check water temperature with unaffected hand before bathing due to impaired pain and temperature sensation (cape-like sensory loss prevents feeling burns)
Inspect hands and arms daily for unnoticed burns, cuts, or injuries due to impaired pain sensation in affected dermatomes
Do not drive until cleared by neurology due to impaired hand dexterity, grip strength deficits, and potential sensory loss affecting safe vehicle operation
Report any new numbness, worsening hand weakness, increasing difficulty with fine motor tasks (buttons, writing), or changes in gait to neurologist promptly as these indicate syrinx progression
After surgery: follow all post-operative activity restrictions; report fever, wound drainage, increasing headache, new weakness, or CSF leak (clear fluid from wound) immediately
Keep follow-up appointments with neurosurgery and neurology; repeat MRI will be needed at regular intervals to monitor syrinx size and response to treatment
Perform prescribed physical therapy and occupational therapy exercises between sessions to maintain and improve function

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Fall prevention: remove loose rugs, install grab bars in bathroom, use non-slip mats, adequate lighting, and wear supportive footwear with non-slip soles given gait instability and sensory loss
Avoid heavy lifting and Valsalva maneuvers (straining, forceful coughing, heavy exertion) as these may increase intraspinal pressure and potentially worsen syrinx
Burn prevention: use oven mitts, test water temperature with unaffected body parts, avoid prolonged heat exposure to denervated skin areas to prevent unrecognized thermal injuries

Low-impact exercise program (swimming in supervised setting, stationary cycling, walking with assistive device if needed) to maintain cardiovascular fitness and muscle strength without high-impact loading
Ergonomic workstation setup: maintain neutral spine position, avoid prolonged neck flexion, use supportive chair, take breaks every 30 minutes to reduce mechanical stress on spine
Weight management to reduce axial loading on spine and optimize surgical outcomes
Smoking cessation to improve surgical outcomes and reduce pseudarthrosis risk if cervical fusion is needed
Bowel program maintenance with adequate fiber (25-30 g/day), fluid intake (2L/day), and regular toileting schedule to prevent neurogenic bowel complications
Depression and anxiety screening at each follow-up visit using PHQ-9 and GAD-7; chronic progressive myelopathy carries high rates of mood disorders
Skin protection program for areas with sensory loss: daily inspection, moisturizing, protective clothing, avoiding prolonged pressure on insensate areas

differential.features: Progressive myelopathy from extrinsic cord compression; no intramedullary cavity; spondylotic changes on imaging; typically older patients; similar symptoms but different mechanism
differential.tests: MRI cervical spine (extrinsic compression without intramedullary cavity; T2 signal from myelomalacia vs defined syrinx cavity); CT cervical spine (osteophytes, disc disease)

differential.features: Relapsing-remitting course; short-segment cord lesions (<3 vertebral segments); brain lesions (periventricular, juxtacortical); optic neuritis; Lhermitte sign; young adults
differential.tests: MRI brain (periventricular/juxtacortical lesions); CSF oligoclonal bands; cord lesion pattern (eccentric, short segment in MS vs central longitudinal syrinx cavity)

differential.diagnosis: Intramedullary spinal cord tumor (ependymoma, astrocytoma, hemangioblastoma)
differential.features: Enhancing intramedullary mass on MRI; associated syrinx may be present (tumor-associated syrinx); progressive course; may have hemorrhage (hemangioblastoma)
differential.tests: MRI spine with gadolinium (enhancing mass; tumor caps at syrinx poles in ependymoma); spinal angiography if vascular tumor; biopsy for tissue diagnosis

differential.features: Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (>3 segments); central cord involvement; severe attacks with poor recovery; optic neuritis; area postrema syndrome
differential.tests: AQP4-IgG antibody (serum); MRI brain (area postrema, periependymal lesions); cord lesion is inflammatory, not cystic cavity

differential.features: Combined upper and lower motor neuron signs WITHOUT sensory findings; fasciculations; bulbar symptoms; progressive course without pain or sensory loss
differential.tests: EMG/NCS (diffuse denervation in 3+ regions); no sensory loss on exam; no cord cavity on MRI; no bladder dysfunction initially

differential.features: Older male; progressive myelopathy; flow voids on MRI; dorsal cord edema; may have secondary syrinx; stepwise or progressive course
differential.tests: MRI (flow voids, dorsal cord edema); spinal angiography (gold standard — identifies fistula location)

differential.features: Symmetric posterior column dysfunction (proprioception, vibration loss) + corticospinal tract signs; macrocytic anemia; cognitive changes; peripheral neuropathy
differential.tests: Serum B12; methylmalonic acid; homocysteine; CBC (macrocytosis); MRI (posterior column T2 signal without syrinx cavity)

differential.features: Family history; slowly progressive bilateral lower extremity spasticity; onset often younger; minimal sensory findings; normal MRI structurally (no syrinx)
differential.tests: Genetic testing (SPG genes); family history; MRI spine (cord atrophy without cavity); EMG/NCS

differential.features: CSF-intensity cyst displacing cord externally; no intramedullary cavity; mass effect on cord from outside; may cause myelopathy from compression
differential.tests: MRI spine (extramedullary CSF-signal lesion distinct from intramedullary syrinx); CT myelogram shows communication vs non-communication with subarachnoid space

differential.features: Systemic features (pulmonary, skin, lymphadenopathy); enhancing cord lesion; leptomeningeal enhancement; elevated ACE; may cause secondary syrinx from arachnoiditis
differential.tests: ACE level; chest CT (hilar lymphadenopathy); MRI (enhancing cord/meningeal lesion); CSF (elevated protein, pleocytosis); biopsy (non-caseating granulomas)

evidence.recommendation: Posterior fossa decompression is first-line surgical treatment for Chiari I-associated syringomyelia; majority of patients show syrinx reduction
evidence.source: [Milhorat et al. J Neurosurg (1999)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10235728/); large surgical series demonstrating syrinx improvement in 80% after decompression

evidence.recommendation: Duraplasty in addition to bony decompression improves CSF flow restoration and syrinx resolution compared to bony decompression alone
evidence.source: [Zhao et al. Neurosurg Rev (2017)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27638711/); meta-analysis comparing duraplasty vs extradural-only decompression

evidence.recommendation: Cine-MRI CSF flow studies predict surgical outcomes and guide operative planning in Chiari-associated syringomyelia
evidence.source: [Bunck et al. Neuroradiology (2012)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21833738/); 4D phase-contrast MRI demonstrates CSF flow dynamics at craniocervical junction

evidence.recommendation: Syringosubarachnoid shunting effective for post-traumatic and non-Chiari syringomyelia with progressive neurologic deficit
evidence.source: [Batzdorf et al. J Neurosurg Spine (2013)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23682808/); long-term outcomes of shunting for non-communicating syrinx

evidence.recommendation: Natural history studies show that small, asymptomatic syrinxes may remain stable without treatment; conservative management reasonable for stable, asymptomatic cases
evidence.source: [Strahle et al. J Neurosurg Pediatr (2015)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25745949/); long-term follow-up of incidentally discovered syrinxes

evidence.recommendation: Gabapentin and pregabalin effective for central neuropathic pain associated with spinal cord pathology
evidence.source: [Finnerup et al. Lancet Neurol (2015)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25575710/); NeuPSIG guidelines for neuropathic pain

evidence.recommendation: Baclofen first-line for spasticity in spinal cord conditions including syringomyelia
evidence.source: Expert consensus; extensive clinical experience; [Taricco et al. Cochrane (2000)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10796750/)

evidence.recommendation: Tumor-associated syrinx often resolves with complete tumor resection; separate syrinx shunting usually not required
evidence.source: [Samii et al. Neurosurgery (2001)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11504096/); large series of intramedullary tumor resection with syrinx resolution

evidence.recommendation: DVT prophylaxis in acute myelopathy with immobilization
evidence.source: High thrombotic risk in immobilized patients with spinal cord dysfunction; [Geerts et al. Chest (2008)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18574271/)

evidence.recommendation: Tethered cord release may improve or stabilize syringomyelia associated with occult spinal dysraphism
evidence.source: [Klekamp et al. J Neurosurg Spine (2012)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22559277/); surgical outcomes for tethered cord-associated syrinx

evidence.recommendation: Serial MRI monitoring recommended for all syringomyelia patients regardless of treatment approach; interval depends on clinical stability
evidence.source: Expert consensus; [Heiss et al. J Neurosurg (2012)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22746571/); natural history and monitoring protocols

evidence.recommendation: Intermittent catheterization preferred over indwelling catheter for neurogenic bladder in syringomyelia
evidence.source: Spinal cord injury guidelines; lower UTI rates with intermittent catheterization

monitoring.item: Neurologic exam (motor strength, sensory level — especially pain/temperature dissociation, reflexes, gait assessment, hand dexterity)
monitoring.frequency: ED: at presentation; HOSP: q4-8h x 48h, then q shift; OPD: each visit; ICU: q2-4h
monitoring.action: If worsening motor exam or expanding sensory deficit: STAT MRI; urgent neurosurgical consult

monitoring.item: Syrinx size on MRI (length, anteroposterior diameter, transverse diameter)
monitoring.frequency: 3-6 months post-treatment; then annually for first 5 years; then q2-3 years if stable
monitoring.action: Increasing syrinx size: neurosurgical reassessment; evaluate for shunt malfunction, re-tethering, or new obstruction

monitoring.item: CSF flow on cine-MRI (if post-Chiari decompression)
monitoring.frequency: 3-6 months post-operative; if syrinx not improving
monitoring.action: Persistent CSF flow obstruction: consider revision surgery or additional decompression

monitoring.item: Respiratory function (FVC, NIF) — if high cervical syrinx (C3-C5)
monitoring.frequency: q4-6h if high cervical syrinx with respiratory symptoms; q2h if declining
monitoring.action: FVC <20 mL/kg or NIF weaker than -30 cmH2O: ICU transfer; prepare for intubation

monitoring.frequency: At initial evaluation; daily inpatient; each outpatient visit initially; q3-6 months when stable
monitoring.action: PVR >200 mL: start intermittent catheterization; >500 mL: Foley catheter; urology referral

monitoring.item: Pain assessment (NRS 0-10; neuropathic pain screening — DN4 or LANSS)
monitoring.frequency: At initial evaluation; daily inpatient; each outpatient visit
monitoring.action: NRS >6 despite treatment: escalate analgesics; consider pain management referral; distinguish nociceptive vs neuropathic

monitoring.item: Gait assessment (10-meter walk test; Timed Up and Go)
monitoring.frequency: At initial evaluation; each outpatient visit; post-operatively at 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months
monitoring.action: Progressive gait deterioration: urgent neurosurgical reassessment; PT intensification; repeat MRI

monitoring.item: Sensory mapping (pain/temperature dissociation distribution — cape-like pattern)
monitoring.frequency: At initial evaluation; each outpatient visit; after any intervention
monitoring.action: Expanding sensory deficit: STAT MRI; neurosurgical reassessment for syrinx expansion

monitoring.item: Post-operative wound and CSF leak assessment
monitoring.action: CSF leak: wound exploration; oversewing; lumbar drain; pseudomeningocele: observation vs surgical repair

monitoring.frequency: q6h while on IV steroids; daily on oral taper
monitoring.action: Sliding scale insulin; endocrine consult if persistent hyperglycemia

monitoring.item: Skin assessment (insensate areas for unrecognized injury)
monitoring.frequency: q shift inpatient; each outpatient visit
monitoring.action: Wound care; patient re-education on skin protection; occupational therapy for adaptive strategies

disposition.criteria: Stable neurologic exam; ambulatory without significant fall risk (with or without assistive device); independent bladder function (PVR <200 mL); adequate pain control on oral medications; MRI completed; follow-up appointments arranged with neurology and neurosurgery; home environment safe for sensory deficit; reliable follow-up within 2-4 weeks

Progressive neurologic deficit (new weakness, expanding sensory loss) requiring observation; inability to ambulate safely; neurogenic bladder requiring catheterization; new diagnosis requiring urgent workup; pending surgical evaluation; inadequate pain control; need for inpatient PT/OT assessment; post-operative monitoring after uncomplicated surgery

High cervical syrinx (C3-C5) with respiratory compromise (FVC <20 mL/kg); post-operative monitoring after complex neurosurgical procedure (posterior fossa decompression with duraplasty); rapidly progressive quadriparesis; hemodynamic instability; post-operative CSF leak requiring close monitoring
Need for neurosurgery not available at current facility; need for cine-MRI or specialized imaging not available; need for neurology/neurosurgery subspecialty input in syringomyelia management

Significant motor deficits preventing independent ADLs; gait impairment requiring assistive device training; neurogenic bladder/bowel requiring structured program; able to participate in 3 hours/day of therapy
Unable to tolerate 3 hours/day of intensive rehabilitation; requires skilled nursing care; ongoing wound care; cannot return home safely due to degree of disability
